section.text: Good morning. Thanks a lot for taking my question. Conor, last quarter, you qualified the results with cautious optimism. This quarter, the market was described as uncertain and challenging. Can you talk about what you're seeing in your seat on the overall market and how it's evolving? And presumably, tenants are starting to have conversations about 2023 store openings.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Michael Goldsmith", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "539f5a4c-ecde-4c08-923a-1f09beddf02e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Has there been any change in posture to their thought process? And I recognize you have a lot of different tenant types, but just trying to understand the change in tone and how that may translate to tenant demand kind of in the upcoming year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Michael Goldsmith", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "539f5a4c-ecde-4c08-923a-1f09beddf02e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at UBS"}

section.text: Sure. It's a great question. I think when you think about how we've positioned ourselves, we continue to think our portfolio is poised for growth. And so our cautious optimism remains. Our strength of our portfolio and our team is shining through as you see the results, really continue on the same path as previous quarter. On the macro side, clearly, the cloud have gotten darker on the horizon, there's more uncertainty.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "05f16d4c-5e81-4e8b-9184-c22e7e2f60f9", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So when you get those types of flashing warning signs, you need to make sure you prepare for what may come next. And that's where I think the tone in our earnings scripts have tried to outline exactly how we're focused on preparing for what could be a challenging environment. Now the good part for Kimco is we've got a very battle-tested team and the portfolio has been transformed.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "05f16d4c-5e81-4e8b-9184-c22e7e2f60f9", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So when you look at the supply and demand dynamic for the Kimco portfolio and the resilient Kimco consumer, we feel like because we offer that value and convenience component, we should be in a very good position to weather any type of storm come next year. So overall, the retailer commentary has not changed. 2023 is pretty much based by this point.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "05f16d4c-5e81-4e8b-9184-c22e7e2f60f9", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: When you look at the retailer open device. Most of those deals have already been solidified. They're already looking for deals in 2024, and they haven't slowed down. There's still a lot of demand out there. In a lot of ways, this might be the best leasing environment we've ever seen because of the depth and breadth of the retailer demand and the lack of supply.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "05f16d4c-5e81-4e8b-9184-c22e7e2f60f9", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Good morning everyone. Hi Conor, in your opening comments, you talked about seeking growth opportunities given your financial strength. Maybe elaborate kind of on that statement and kind of what that opportunity set could potentially look like, let's say, over the next 12 to 18 months, especially in light of -- given the recent monetization of Albertsons that you've done. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Samir Khanal", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "6d7a3722-de4e-42a2-a43f-346ecf78b60e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore"}

section.text: We're happy to, and Ross, you can chime in as well. Clearly, we've got a nice landscape of opportunities when we look forward. With our liquidity positioning, it's pretty unique to come into a point where banks are already pulling back. You're not seeing a lot of bond deals getting done. You're seeing a lot of floating rate debt that's coming to maturity. You're seeing a lot of CMBS maturity coming up.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "ec2534fc-87ce-4b44-a863-5c2653ea2ac1", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: That typically signals distress or some type of dislocation where if you've got dry powder, you can pretty much take advantage of it. So when we look at our unique set of opportunities, clearly, we'd love to buy core acquisitions with growth embedded in the cash flow. Those have been hard to come by in our markets where we continue to mine for those unique opportunities.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "ec2534fc-87ce-4b44-a863-5c2653ea2ac1", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: What we have found a little bit more on the opportunity side is on the preferred -- structure. We continue to think that, that capital at the higher return is a nice opportunity for us to get a foot in the door with a ROFR or ROFO to have a future acquisition opportunity on that asset. And that may be something that, again, may come into focus next year as capital starts to get tightened up.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "ec2534fc-87ce-4b44-a863-5c2653ea2ac1", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Yes. No, in a lot of ways, these environments are where we have the ability to do our most attractive deals. Just looking back to the onset of the pandemic in 2020 and early 2021, I think we were able to accomplish some really unique opportunistic investments that became much more challenging over the last 12 months as the market recovered. A lot of that fast money that came in 1031 exchanges, and we're really pushing pricing have all subsided at this point.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "d3f9a21e-b261-4bad-885b-536e4b8693c5", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So in a lot of ways, we think 2023 will be the perfect environment for us to go back out there and to find some really attractive structured investments. We continue to have conversations with all of our joint venture partners to see who may have an interest in monetizing in a choppy environment. And as Conor mentioned, while the bid-ask spread on the core acquisitions have been wide of late, we do hang around the hoop and have lots of open dialogue with brokers and a lot of owners that they consider selling next year, and we'll be ready to do that with our liquidity position and move quickly at given the opportunity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "d3f9a21e-b261-4bad-885b-536e4b8693c5", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Good morning. Glenn, in line with your goal to retain as much cash as possible from Albertsons proceeds as you had mentioned in your opening remarks, how much might you push that kind of share to cash ratio on the special dividend?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Greg McGinniss", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "ce2dbd6c-79d4-4291-b930-6ac3dad25c00", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Deutsche Bank"}

section.text: I'm sorry, can you repeat just the last part? I didn't hear it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "cae9bddd-048a-4f79-9bda-4a2b18b088d6", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: How much might you push the share versus cash distribution on the special dividend?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Greg McGinniss", "section_number": 10, "uuid": "6c7f2509-4764-46fa-a80e-6af211bbb1db", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Deutsche Bank"}

section.text: Yes, so we haven't finalized it yet. It's something that we still need to go over with the Board. There's a requirement to do a minimum of 20% in cash, so we will finalize it over time. But I mean, ideally, we're going to try and retain as much cash as we can. And again, it's the shareholders all may hold relative to any stock dividend that we would issue since it's pro rata amongst the full range of shares -- shareholders.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "525dfe85-94fc-4292-9a40-7a5f89081fc1", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Hi. Good morning. And thanks for the time. Just maybe a question for Glenn on the guidance. I think you walked through it and apologies if I missed it, what the driver is from an FFO perspective on the implied fourth quarter to sell for FFO. And then just curious if you can give more comments as part of that on the same-store NOI guidance. I believe you're at 5% year-to-date, but you're kind of holding the commentary about just being positive. So maybe you could just give a little bit more context around some of the puts and takes for same-store NOI?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Juan Sanabria", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "be353882-84db-43f5-8f7e-31ab1698b830", "speaker_title": "Analyst at BMO Capital Markets"}

section.text: Sure. So first, just on the guidance. So we didn't -- as I mentioned, we did raise the guidance to $1.57, $1.59 from the previous level. We are comfortable, quite candidly, at the upper end of the range. So that would imply roughly a $0.39 fourth quarter. As I mentioned, the third quarter did have about $0.02 of, call it, one timers in there from the fair market value amortization that came through a couple of million dollars of LTA.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "9e8e8ad6-b787-4f94-88de-4551655d4364", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So we feel pretty comfortable at the upper end of the range as it relates to guidance. So on the same-site NOI, I would say we're going to probably be close to way you saw us in the third quarter in that range, probably in that 3%-ish range when you look at the whole -- looking at it all together, again, we are up against a pretty tough comp of over 12%. But I think it will be pretty close to where we saw the third quarter.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "9e8e8ad6-b787-4f94-88de-4551655d4364", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Again, credit loss income has come down significantly. And as I mentioned, we really think we've come to the end of -- we're having income from credit loss and a little -- start to revert back towards something more in line with what you've seen previously, 75 basis points plus of credit loss over time.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "9e8e8ad6-b787-4f94-88de-4551655d4364", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Hey, good morning. So I guess maybe one for Ross on the transaction side, given your activity here in the quarter. I was curious, maybe you could give us some perspective on cap rates. I know they're moving, but curious on where you transacted on your acquisition dispositions during the quarter. When those occurred, I think it was probably early in the quarter. And then where do you peg cap rates today? And then what would you need to see in terms of cap rates to get more active, given your higher cost of capital here? Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Haendel St. Juste", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "d3c3cdea-11ba-4448-b9a3-7091ab2019b4", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Mizuho"}

section.text: Sure. Yes, I mean cap rates are certainly a bit of a moving target in this environment. While they don't go necessarily basis point for basis point with interest rates, there has been a little bit of a lag as rates have risen pretty dramatically. So it is a little bit difficult to peg exactly where deals are today particularly because, as I mentioned, deals that are not previously committed as of the last 45 to 60 days plus, you're really seeing a bit of a pause in the marketplace today, where I think buyers are still comfortable moving forward on core acquisitions are not necessarily where sellers are willing to sell today.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "74956ccd-d94f-4da8-8a2d-17c650bff0a9", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Now that might start to change if you see a little bit more distressed in force selling, which I think will start to mark where cap rates will transact that. But right now, you're seeing a pretty wide bid-ask spread. But clearly, the sub-5 cap grocery-anchored shopping center transactions that we saw through the first half of the year are not penciling for investors today.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "74956ccd-d94f-4da8-8a2d-17c650bff0a9", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: The deals that we did close in the quarter were all based upon an in-place cap rate that were in the mid- to high 5s. Again, as we talked about in previous quarters, for us in looking at cap rates, it really is just a spot check at a point in time. I think in the prepared remarks, we talked a little bit about some of the vacancy and the assets that we acquired, which will really be able to fuel our growth and get our CAGR and our IRRs to an acceptable level.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "74956ccd-d94f-4da8-8a2d-17c650bff0a9", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So while cap rate is something that we do factor in, it's not the end all deal metric that we look at. So we'll be watching very closely the good position that we're in enables us to move once the capitulation with sellers starts to occur. But clearly, we're waiting for a little bit more clarity on where sellers are willing to transact before you see a whole lot of closings occurring certainly by the end of this year and as we get into the beginning of next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "74956ccd-d94f-4da8-8a2d-17c650bff0a9", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Hey,-- good morning. It sounds like it's a one question. So I'm going to focus on the Albertsons and the tax and the dividends and capital gains and all that fun stuff. Can you just provide to the extent that you can disclose how much of Albertsons sits in the TRS? How much is in the REIT? Abilities to either manage the taxable gain. It doesn't sound -- it sounds like you're already paying out sort of your taxable income, but maybe there's some stuff coming up next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Alexander Goldfarb", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "4bd6ad2c-fa19-40a2-8b26-74379b9f714b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: But just give some perspective and then also more color on what do you mean tax credit that shareholders get. In REIT land, we don't normally hear about that. So maybe just a little bit more color on that aspect as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Alexander Goldfarb", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "4bd6ad2c-fa19-40a2-8b26-74379b9f714b", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Piper Sandler"}

section.text: Great question, Alex. And you're right. This is definitely not the norm for the REIT sector at all. So it's a really great problem to have, I guess, I'll call it. So first of all, all the shares today sit in the REIT, years -- well, now, I guess, six years ago. Previously, we had in 2016, the shares were in the TRS, we have merged them back into our REIT. And upon waiting five years, which has passed, any of the built-in gain related to the shares in the TRS really expired.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "c8ed4db2-fd9f-47ff-844b-bd778a072ab4", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So now all the shares are sitting in the REIT. So now it's a matter of as we deal with the gain, it's a capital gain. So we have to first make sure that we are staying in compliance with the REIT tests, one of the REIT test being the gross income test. So we've monitored that, and we're fine. The capital gain then the question is how best to retain the capital for future investment, debt reduction all the things that we do in the business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "c8ed4db2-fd9f-47ff-844b-bd778a072ab4", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So we have decided that we're going to pay the capital gains tax on the piece that we've monetized. And as I mentioned, that tax is about $60 million. With us paying as a REIT, with us paying the capital gain tax, we are going to provide information that all of the shareholders are entitled to a credit, not as adoption, but credits they have pro rata share of the tax that we've paid.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "c8ed4db2-fd9f-47ff-844b-bd778a072ab4", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So there's a form to be filed and tax returns that might be filed by non-exempts, but there's a clear path to getting that cash even if you're a nontax paying entity.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "c8ed4db2-fd9f-47ff-844b-bd778a072ab4", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: We plan to provide pretty significant detail on that, on our website as well as our reach to our shareholder base so that they understand the roadmap that they need to take. I think it's -- as you said, it's a unique situation. And we'll make sure we allocate time and effort to have everybody understand what they need to do to get that tax credit.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "b85e21d9-2106-4202-a343-ff83a4ff5121", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: And then the other thing I'd add is we still own 28.3 million shares of stock. And that our expectation is that over the next two tax years, 2023, 2024, we'll monetize it. And that will allow us to maximize retaining as much cash as we can as we continue to work through the distribution requirements.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "cbc44362-00e8-45f0-9531-87be436415dd", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Hey, guys. Just a quick question as Ross and was running through the investment environment through guidance. There was no mention of the $400 million acquisition in Long Island that you guys have talked about in the press. Just curious, is that still on the table here? Or should we think about that as sort of being pumped or delayed into 2023?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Craig Mailman", "section_number": 24, "uuid": "09f9490a-c23e-4206-9d76-0b659d6d376e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Citi"}

section.text: Sure. Yes. I mean, look, our policy has really been not to comment on transactions until they close. We do anticipate that there will be additional closings this year in the next 60 days on both the acquisition and the disposition side. So we'll certainly provide more detail as soon as any of those transactions do close. The one thing that I would comment on the life cycle of some of these deals is that they all have their own nuances and they all have significantly different timeframes. Our bread and butter, all cash transaction, can close very quickly.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "49fcb6ed-ac58-4ff9-8568-e66e9638addf", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Other larger portfolio transactions oftentimes have different nuances that may include loan assumptions or very significant accretive tax structuring. So to that point, certain deals do take quite a while to get from the initial conversation to the closing line. So as soon as we have more details to provide on any of these deals as they close, we'll be happy to provide that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "49fcb6ed-ac58-4ff9-8568-e66e9638addf", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Good morning. Thanks very much for taking my question. I wanted to actually follow up a little bit on Haendel's question. Would not necessarily talk about yields and yield expectations because, as you rightly point out, that can be a moving target, Ross. But maybe if you can talk about what has happened to your IRR expectations since the beginning of the year? And how do you see that evolving over the next 12 months as well?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Floris Van Dijkum", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "2707857c-68b8-4934-bef3-01a598680d9d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Compass Point"}

section.text: Yes. No, that's a good question. We absolutely look at our cost of capital on a daily basis. So while cap rates are a moving target, frankly our internal hurdles are also a bit of a moving target. What I can tell you is that from an unlevered IRR perspective, at a minimum we're looking at transactions that have to clear high single digits, low double digits.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "446e8fe7-c236-440a-849c-fab9e55666df", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: In this environment, we're hopeful that there's going to be some more opportunistic -- investment opportunities that will be certainly in the double digits. So from our perspective, we have a host of potential deals in 2023 that we're targeting that should absolutely be able to flip that. So we're staying patient. We're in a good position right now. While the Albertsons monetization has a very low hurdle to clear to be accretive and that we were only getting about 2% yield, our internal expectations are clearly much higher than that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Ross Cooper", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "446e8fe7-c236-440a-849c-fab9e55666df", "speaker_title": "President & Chief Investment Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Thank you. I noticed that the operating expense increased by 16.5% and year-to-date is up 4.8%. As a run rate, can we expect closer to the double-digit gains in operation expense?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Craig Schmidt", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "1f62a682-846d-4ced-b74d-b5e9ce41e9e6", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America"}

section.text: Craig, it's a good question. I think we're going to have to get back to you on the detail on that breakdown. I think the operating expenses may have some onetime items in there to create that type of jump. But we'll unpack that and give you the detail and follow up with you. I don't think you'll see that continue. I think we've done a pretty good job of making sure we manage our operating expenses and don't see any sort of spikes that we can't control. So we'll get back to you on that one.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "7bc9795c-927a-47fa-bc50-0418e85274f9", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Thanks. Good morning. Just want to go back to your earlier comments about 2023, and I think you mentioned that you're expecting a credit loss reserve of 75 to 100 basis points. I was wondering if you could just put -- if you can frame that for us, what that looks like in a typical normal year? I realize we haven't had a normal year in a while. And how much of that reserve account for tenants that are pretty much identified versus just a buffer for things that might come from like left field?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ki Bin Kim", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "e711b036-d3e6-4223-b9e6-fa891dc4fb38", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Truist Securities"}

section.text: Yes. Sure. Sure, Ki. So the credit loss historically pre-pandemic for a pretty long run rate was running somewhere in that 60 to 75 basis points per year range. So just mathematically, if you look at it, if we're in this 75 to 100 basis point target area or expectation area because of where we're viewing the economy and the uncertainty in it, you're looking at something in a dollar range of around $18 million.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "1f149776-929a-4b74-9bfb-29c39e8d3934", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So $15 million to $20 million in total on that 75 to 100 basis point spread. So that will give you an idea. It is not targeted or specific to any particular tenant. I mean the -- our tenants at risk, the list is actually pretty short today. But again, we're watching pretty closely. It's been a long cycle of not a lot of bankruptcies. So the tenants have held up incredibly well. But again, we're in a pretty uncertain time. There's a lot of rhetoric around recession coming and what that might mean. So our approach is just to be cautious about how we guide.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "1f149776-929a-4b74-9bfb-29c39e8d3934", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Great. Just a quick one for me on just the financing markets. Just number one, can you remind us where you could sort of issue debt today? I recognize you may not need to and so forth, that would be helpful. And then the second piece of it is, if I just take a step back and I think about the 2025 target that the team has put out. Clearly, we're in a different sort of interest rate environment, financing environment for retailers, for REITs. Maybe can you just comment on what you think changes potentially in this new environment?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Ronald Kamdem", "section_number": 36, "uuid": "c59df9c1-d20a-413c-a209-ada05d794c5c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Morgan Stanley"}

section.text: So I'll take the first part of your question. I would say that we're really, really happy that we went to the market when we did and we found a very small open window to do the issuance we did. We pushed our debt maturities out, so we have no debt maturing for the balance of this year or really -- 2023. It is interesting, as rates have risen pretty dramatically normally, we would have expected spreads to come in a little bit.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "1f579aa7-5cf7-41ac-82bb-64731f76e333", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: But I would tell you, spreads are wider today than the day we issued. Our issuance was done at 190 over. We're probably in the 220 range in terms of spread today on a 10-year. So you can do the math, but treasury today is around 410. So you're looking at somewhere around a coupon of around 635 to probably 640. So again, we have no need to go to the market.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "1f579aa7-5cf7-41ac-82bb-64731f76e333", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: The nice part about our debt is all the consolidated debt is virtually fixed rate and for a pretty long time at 9.7 years. So we don't have short-term exposure to the rate environment. And like anything else, we'll continue to look at the debt stock and be opportunistic where we can and look to repay future bonds at an appropriate time.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "1f579aa7-5cf7-41ac-82bb-64731f76e333", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Your question about the 2025 goals, I think that we're consistent in trying to make sure that we set goals that we want to try and achieve that might be somewhat aspirational, but we want to push each other to try and reach those goals. Clearly, financing market has changed pretty dramatically. You see the cash flow growth continuing. That's the exciting part about our business.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "1ba704c0-3907-4174-9132-7777665fb765", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: The fundamentals are quite strong. When you look at the leasing demand and the lack of supply and the stickiness factor that we're seeing with our retention rates, we continue to think the business is on a very solid footing. And so we'll continue to monitor that situation. But we've got a lot of future entitlement goals that we plan to hit as well. We've secured 1,500 units this year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "1ba704c0-3907-4174-9132-7777665fb765", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: We'd like to get that up to maybe 1,800 to 2,000 by the end of the year. So we're stretching to hit that and continue to think that when times get tough, typically municipalities sometimes loosen up on entitlements, because that's usually when they're trying to find ways to increase their tax base and find ways to increase the operations of their municipalities. So hopefully, we can secure even more entitlements if things do get tough.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "1ba704c0-3907-4174-9132-7777665fb765", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Before we go to the next question, I just want to clarify to Craig Smith's question on operating expenses, the increase in operating expenses really was derived from having a full quarter of Weingarten in our portfolio this quarter. We closed in August of last year, so now we have a full three months this quarter. If you look at our operating expense ratio margin, which we put in the supplemental this quarter, you can actually see we're recovering more than we had previously. So to Conor's point, we're doing a better job there. You could take the next question.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David F. Bujnicki", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "fe2a59fb-eec6-4e21-85f8-dbdcbae0cceb", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategy at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Hey, good morning everyone. It's Wes. Just a quick question on the Albertsons monetization potential for next year. Would that be a cleaner year where you call it monetize $375 million and you wouldn't have to pay any taxes, you'd be able to retain all the cash flow. And then when we look into 2024, if you get the bigger lump sum, we may be looking at a scenario that is more like this year where you may have some cap gains that you have to distribute.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Wes Golladay", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "61690f7c-b32e-4dcb-8a9c-9a2f094c84bb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Baird"}

section.text: And then if I could get an unrelated second part question in here. I'm just kind of curious why the JVs have higher floating rate debt. We're seeing that for many companies. I just didn't know if it was something the partners were pushing for.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Wes Golladay", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "61690f7c-b32e-4dcb-8a9c-9a2f094c84bb", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Baird"}

section.text: Great question. So let me take the Albertsons first, and then I'll talk about the JV part. So if you look at where our current dividend is, we are very, very close to where taxable income and the dividend are really in line, but just from the recurring operations. It does not include what was a capital gain from the remainder of Albertsons. So it's going to require additional tax strategies, deductions that we can find along the way to shelter some of that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "0db69dac-77a5-4a4c-a876-64eb151ee28c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: If not, we would be in the same position actually this year where we would have to either pay the tax to retain as much capital. Those are our options. I mean, because we are keeping the dividend, it's really important for us to keep the dividend based on the recurring operations to keep that FAD number in that low 70s percent range and leave lots of pushing for us.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "0db69dac-77a5-4a4c-a876-64eb151ee28c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So the specials, we just have to deal with them as they come along and look for whatever shelter we can find. As it relates to the JVs, again some of it is because -- again, they're somewhat sometimes viewed as a little bit more transitional. We've had, as you've seen, we've brought a lot of properties out of the joint ventures over time. So it's been -- it's kind of an agreement between the partners how they want to do it. In the care portfolio, we actually have almost fully -- an unencumbered pool of properties that's financed with unsecured bank debt.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "0db69dac-77a5-4a4c-a876-64eb151ee28c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So there it's been done as floating rate, and it's been fine because the leverage is so low to just keep it floating for now. But you are right, we do use more floating rate debt within the JVs than anything in the parent. And it's a combination of working with the partners
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "Glenn Gary Cohen", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "0db69dac-77a5-4a4c-a876-64eb151ee28c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President, Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: I think the partners like it to give them a little bit more flexibility to, if they want to put the asset on the market for sale, that they, in essence, take out the floating rate. So I think that's part of it as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Conor C. Flynn", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "2b1a1cb0-b957-4836-83f7-2a038e7bb2d9", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer and Director at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Yes, hi. I guess looking at the size of your redevelopment and mixed-use pipelines and just given the backdrop today, can the size of that pipeline stay the same over the next couple of years as projects are completed? Or should we think of it as likely contracting some?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Mike Mueller", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "2f2e3f38-24fb-46d3-a4e3-2e2b66470dea", "speaker_title": "Analyst at JPMorgan"}

section.text: Thanks, Mike. Appreciate the question. I was been quiet over here, so glad I could jump in at the end. We're very opportunistic with our redevelopment pipeline. As you know, the extent of our entitlement program is pretty exhaustive with thousands of units that are entitled, ready to go when the market's warranted and what our cost of capital is such, and we can find a structure that makes sense.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David Jamieson", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "ee715588-b734-4f5b-9ffc-a843fd786a9c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: And we're looking at multiple projects in the near-term that could potentially activate while considering all those other variables I just mentioned. The good thing about our program is the markets in which we operate in, there's still clear demand for the product, especially on the multifamily side. You hear a lot of headlines, you read a lot of headlines related to the undersupply in the residential market.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "David Jamieson", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "ee715588-b734-4f5b-9ffc-a843fd786a9c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: So there is housing demand that's very much a driver of the opportunity as well in California, Florida, etc. So we continue to look at that. In terms of our core redevelopment pipeline that we continue to activate, it is driven by leasing, right, and the opportunities there. As Conor mentioned in his earlier remarks, the leasing demand is such that we really have the COVID inventory that's getting absorbed quickly.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "David Jamieson", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "ee715588-b734-4f5b-9ffc-a843fd786a9c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: Retailers are very much out there trying to hit their open-to-buy targets to achieve their growth goals. And our core redevelopment program fits right into that to help solve for their needs and our needs and build a better mousetrap. So we continue to see a nice healthy cadence in case in the coming year. And again, hear more in the coming quarters about the rest of the program.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "David Jamieson", "section_number": 46, "uuid": "ee715588-b734-4f5b-9ffc-a843fd786a9c", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer at Kimco Realty"}

section.text: We appreciate everybody taking the time to join us today for the earnings call. We hope you enjoy the rest of your day.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "David F. Bujnicki", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "a3099032-712f-4410-bb31-cc678b3f9a28", "speaker_title": "Senior Vice President of Investor Relations and Strategy at Kimco Realty"}

title: Q&A for KIM (Kimco Realty) on 10/27/22 8:30 AM ET
